{{See also|Human rights in Syria}}

Syria has been under Emergency Law since 1962, effectively suspending most constitutional protections for citizens. In 1963, following the [[February 1963 Iraqi coup d'Ã©tat|Ba'athist overthrow]] success in Iraq, the Ba'ath party [[1963 Syrian coup d'Ã©tat|took power]] in Syria. Despite internal power changes, like the [[1966 Syrian coup d'Ã©tat|1966 coup]] and [[1970 Syrian Corrective Revolution]] the Ba'ath party has remained the sole authority in Syria. Since [[1970 Syrian Corrective Revolution|1970 Revolution]], [[Hafez al-Assad]] had led Syria for 30 years, followed by his son [[Bashar al-Assad]] for the past 10 years.
+
In 1963, following the [[February 1963 Iraqi coup d'Ã©tat|Ba'athist overthrow]] success in Iraq, the Ba'ath party [[1963 Syrian coup d'Ã©tat|took power]] in Syria. Despite internal power changes, like the [[1966 Syrian coup d'Ã©tat|1966 coup]] and [[1970 Syrian Corrective Revolution]] the Ba'ath party has remained the sole authority in Syria.
  +
On 31 January 2011, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' ran an exclusive interview with Bashar al-Assad, [[President]] of [[Syria]], in which he said that it was time to reform. In a comment on the protests in [[Protests in Egypt|Egypt]], [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], he said that a "new era" is coming to the [[Middle East]], and that Arab rulers would need to do more to accommodate their people's rising political and economic aspirations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703833204576114712441122894.html |title=Interview With Syrian President Bashar al-Assad |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704832704576114340735033236.html |title=Syria Strongman: Time for 'Reform' |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> However, President Bashar al-Assad also declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests that have taken place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref>
  +   +
===Inheritance of power===
  +
{{see|Hafez al-Assad}}
  +
{{expand section}}
  +
Since [[1970 Syrian Corrective Revolution|1970 Revolution]], [[Hafez al-Assad]] had led Syria for 30 years, followed by his son [[Bashar al-Assad]] for the past 10 years.
  +   +
===Emergency law===
  +
{{expand section}}
  +
Syria has been under Emergency Law since 1962, effectively suspending most constitutional protections for citizens. Bashar al-Assad has tightened Internet censorship with laws which force Internet cafes to record all the comments users post on chat forums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rsf.org/predator-bashar-al-assad,37213.html |title=Bashar Al-Assad, President, Syria |publisher=Reporters Without Borders }}</ref>
  +
While he has permitted existence of radio stations playing Western pop music, websites such as [[Wikipedia]], [[Youtube]], [[Facebook]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] had been blocked until recently, when, starting on January 1, all citizens have been able to sign up for high speed internet, and those sites were allowed .<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.economist.com/node/11792330 |title=Red lines that cannot be crossed - The authorities donât want you to read or see too much |date=24 July 2008 |publisher=The Economist}}</ref>
  +   +
===Brutality===
  +
{{expand section}}
In 1982, after a 6 year period of Islamic insurgency in the country, the [[Hama massacre]] took place in the city of [[Hama]] as a climax of those events. Hafez al-Assad responded to a [[Muslim Brotherhood]] uprising in Hama by sending a paramilitary force, which killed tens of thousands of people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/683/syrian-reform-what-lies-beneath |first=Farid N. |last=Ghadry |title=Syrian Reform: What Lies Beneath |date=Winter 2005 |publisher=The Middle East Quarterly }}</ref><ref name="The Sturdy House That Assad Built">{{cite web |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/67561/michael-broening/the-sturdy-house-that-assad-built |title=The Sturdy House That Assad Built |date= 7 March 2011 |author=Michael BrÃ¶ning |publisher=The Foreign Affairs }}</ref>
In 1982, after a 6 year period of Islamic insurgency in the country, the [[Hama massacre]] took place in the city of [[Hama]] as a climax of those events. Hafez al-Assad responded to a [[Muslim Brotherhood]] uprising in Hama by sending a paramilitary force, which killed tens of thousands of people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/683/syrian-reform-what-lies-beneath |first=Farid N. |last=Ghadry |title=Syrian Reform: What Lies Beneath |date=Winter 2005 |publisher=The Middle East Quarterly }}</ref><ref name="The Sturdy House That Assad Built">{{cite web |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/67561/michael-broening/the-sturdy-house-that-assad-built |title=The Sturdy House That Assad Built |date= 7 March 2011 |author=Michael BrÃ¶ning |publisher=The Foreign Affairs }}</ref>
In 2004, [[2004 Al-Qamishli riots|anti-government riots]] erupted in the northeastern city of [[Al-Qamishli]]. The riot began during a chaotic soccer match, when some people started raising Kurdish flags, turning the match into a political conflict. In the aftermath of a brutal reaction by Syrian police and clashes between Kurdish and Arab groups, at least 30 people were killed,<ref>{{cite news | first = | last = | author = James Brandon | title = The PKK and Syria's Kurds | url = http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/article.php?articleid=2370250 | publisher = Terrorism Monitor, ''The Jamestown Foundation'' | location = Washington, DC 20036, USA | page = Volume 5, Issue 3 | date = February 15, 2007}}</ref> though other claims indicate a casualty count of about 100.<ref>MidEastWeb. ''Kurdish agony - the forgotten massacre of Qamishlo''. March 2004.[http://www.mideastweb.org/log/archives/00000231.htm] MidEastWeb</ref>
In 2004, [[2004 Al-Qamishli riots|anti-government riots]] erupted in the northeastern city of [[Al-Qamishli]]. The riot began during a chaotic soccer match, when some people started raising Kurdish flags, turning the match into a political conflict. In the aftermath of a brutal reaction by Syrian police and clashes between Kurdish and Arab groups, at least 30 people were killed,<ref>{{cite news | first = | last = | author = James Brandon | title = The PKK and Syria's Kurds | url = http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/article.php?articleid=2370250 | publisher = Terrorism Monitor, ''The Jamestown Foundation'' | location = Washington, DC 20036, USA | page = Volume 5, Issue 3 | date = February 15, 2007}}</ref> though other claims indicate a casualty count of about 100.<ref>MidEastWeb. ''Kurdish agony - the forgotten massacre of Qamishlo''. March 2004.[http://www.mideastweb.org/log/archives/00000231.htm] MidEastWeb</ref>
â
